Relics.Definition: items of great historical or cultural value
Relics.Definition (Cambridge automatic): an object , tradition , or system from the past that continues to exist :

Prolific.Definition: producing a great number of something or having repeated an activity many times
Prolific.Definition (Cambridge automatic): producing a great number or amount of something:

Extensive.Definition (Cambridge automatic): covering a large area ; having a great range :

Get-out-of-jail-free card.Definition: something that is used as an insurance in order to avoid an unpleasant situation, like going to jail. (A reference to the board game Monopoly, in which this card allows players to leave the jail space without missing a turn.)

Bargaining chip.Definition: something that you are prepared to give up in order to reach an agreement and get what you want
Bargaining chip.Definition (Cambridge automatic): something that someone else wants that you are willing to lose in order to reach an agreement :

Collateral.Definition: something used as security for the payment of a loan
Collateral.Definition (Cambridge automatic): valuable property owned by someone who wants to borrow money , that they agree will become the property of the company or person who lends the money if the debt is not paid back:

Estimate.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to guess or calculate the cost , size , value , etc. of something:

Glamorous.Definition: dressing with impressive clothes and being exciting
Glamorous.Definition (Cambridge automatic): attractive in an exciting and special way:

Chateau.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a large house or castle in France

Nondescript.Definition (Cambridge automatic): very ordinary , or having no interesting or exciting features or qualities :

Clue.Definition: information that helps us understand something better
Clue.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a sign or some information that helps you to find the answer to a problem , question , or mystery :

Lavish.Definition (Cambridge automatic): large in quantity and expensive or impressive :

Antique.Definition: dating from a period long ago
Antique.Definition (Cambridge automatic): something made in an earlier period that is collected and considered to have value because it is beautiful , rare , old , or of high quality :

Accomplice.Definition: a person who helps someone to commit a crime
Accomplice.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a person who helps someone else to commit a crime or to do something morally wrong

Partner in crime.Definition: a person who helps someone to commit a crime

Transition.Definition: change from one form to another
Transition.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a change from one form or type to another, or the process by which this happens :

Pistol.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a small gun that is held in and fired from one hand :

Pistols.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a small gun that is held in and fired from one hand :

Resist.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to fight against something or someone that is attacking you:

Machine guns.Definition: automatic guns that can fire lots of bullets very quickly
Machine guns.Definition (Cambridge automatic): an automatic gun that can fire a lot of bullets one after the other very quickly :

Unusual.Definition (Cambridge automatic): different from others of the same type in a way that is surprising , interesting , or attractive :

Snuck into.Definition: went in, in a quiet way so as not to be seen or heard

Threatened.Definition: told someone that he would harm them
Threatened.Definition (Cambridge automatic): in danger , or likely to stop existing :

Antiques.Definition: items dating from a period long ago
Antiques.Definition (Cambridge automatic): something made in an earlier period that is collected and considered to have value because it is beautiful , rare , old , or of high quality :

Disguise.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to give a new appearance to a person or thing, especially in order to hide its TRUE form :

Stockings.Definition: tight-fit coverings for the feet and part of the legs
Stockings.Definition (Cambridge automatic): one of a pair of tight-fitting coverings for the feet and legs made of thin material and often worn under skirts and dresses :

Fingerprints.Definition: the different in every person pattern of lines on the end of a finger
Fingerprints.Definition (Cambridge automatic): the pattern of curved lines on the end of a finger or thumb that is different in every person , or a mark left by this pattern :

Meticulously.Definition: in a way that shows extreme care and attention to detail

Cough.Definition: the act of forcing air out of his lungs suddenly and noisily
Cough.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to force air out of your lungs through your throat with a short , loud sound :

Smash.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to cause something to break noisily into a lot of small pieces :

Screwdriver.Definition: a tool for turning screws (short sharp-pointed metal pins, used to bind two objects together)
Screwdriver.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a tool for turning screws , consisting of a handle joined to a metal rod shaped at one end to fit in the cut in the top of the screw

Unscrew.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to take the lid or top off something by twisting it round:

Purposefully.Definition (Cambridge automatic): in a way that shows that you know what you want to do:

On loan.Definition: for a period of time after which they had to be returned
On loan.Definition (Cambridge automatic): an amount of money that is borrowed , often from a bank , and has to be paid back, usually together with an extra amount of money that you have to pay as a charge for borrowing :

Restoration.Definition: the process of keeping something to its earlier  good condition
Restoration.Definition (Cambridge automatic): the act or process of returning something to its earlier good condition or position , or to its owner :

Maintenance.Definition: the work needed to keep something in good condition
Maintenance.Definition (Cambridge automatic): the work needed to keep a road , building , machine , etc. in good condition :

Recounts.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to describe how something happened , or to tell a story :

Tactic.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a planned way of doing something:

Ironies.Definition: situations in which something is actually the opposite of what would be expected to be
Ironies.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a situation in which something which was intended to have a particular result has the opposite or a very different result :

Toll roads.Definition: roads he has to pay to use
Toll roads.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a road that you pay to use:

The highest bidder.Definition: someone who offers the most money for something
The highest bidder.Definition (Cambridge automatic): someone who offers to pay a particular amount of money for something:

Hopelessly.Definition (Cambridge automatic): extremely , or in a way that makes you lose hope :

Thrill.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a feeling of extreme excitement , usually caused by something pleasant :

Possess.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to have or own something, or to have a particular quality :

Encounters.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a meeting , especially one that happens by chance :

Encounter.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a meeting , especially one that happens by chance :

Persuade.Definition: make them believe they were telling the truth by talking to them
Persuade.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to make someone do or believe something by giving them a good reason to do it or by talking to that person and making them believe it:

Prior.Definition (Cambridge automatic): existing or happening before something else , or before a particular time :

Tended.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to be likely to behave in a particular way or have a particular characteristic :

Scale.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a set of numbers , amounts , etc., used to measure or compare the level of something:

Invincible.Definition (Cambridge automatic): impossible to defeat or prevent from doing what is intended :

Bugle.Definition: a musical instrument like a small trumpet
Bugle.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a musical instrument like a simple trumpet , used especially in the army

Obey.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to act according to what you have been asked or ordered to do by someone in authority , or to behave according to a rule , law , or instruction :

Suspiciously.Definition: in a way that made him think that something is wrong
Suspiciously.Definition (Cambridge automatic): in a way that makes you think that something is wrong :

Denies.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to say that something is not TRUE :

Opportunist.Definition: someone who tries to take advantage of a situation
Opportunist.Definition (Cambridge automatic): someone who tries to get power or an advantage in every situation :

Search warrant.Definition: an official document that would allow them to search his house
Search warrant.Definition (Cambridge automatic): an official document that gives police officers the authority to search a building for stolen property , illegal goods , or information that might help to solve a crime

Expectantly.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to think or believe something will happen , or someone will arrive :

In police custody.Definition: arrested and guarded by the police

Crumble.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to break , or cause something to break , into small pieces :

Pile.Definition: objects positioned on top of each other
Pile.Definition (Cambridge automatic): objects positioned one on top of another:

Canal.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a long , thin stretch of water that is artificially made either for boats to travel along or for taking water from one area to another:

Confessed.Definition: admitted that he had done it
Confessed.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to admit that you have done something wrong or something that you feel guilty or bad about:

To this day.Definition (Cambridge automatic): a period of 24 hours , especially from twelve o'clock one night to twelve o'clock the next night :

Beyond repair.Definition: so damaged that it cannot be repaired
Beyond repair.Definition (Cambridge automatic): to put something that is damaged , broken , or not working correctly , back into good condition or make it work again:

Wept.Definition (Cambridge automatic): past simple and past participle of weep
